Entry.1: Stored kit bag at Chaplin & Co Amesbury.
Entry.2: Pay day. Sent registered letters containing post cards etc to M.B. also papers to & M.B. Rec’d our issue of sheepskin
Entry.3:
Obtained leave Camp as from now and proceeded to London in a bitterly cold Having to wait at Salisbury for train connection. Ronnie Hill and I strolled round town and had afternoon tea. Did not arrive in London until and later in the night I had supper at Corner House to the 

Aldwych but unfortunately no beds were available. Ronnie Hill had however left a note for me to follow him to Shakespeare Hut and after running about in the YMCA motor I eventually arrived there and had some refreshment & bed.
Entry.4: After breakfast to Strand – made a few purchases returned to Camp by 11 train from Waterloo. The train was a beauty and did not stop once. On arrival at Camp it was bitterly cold and at night we had a few flakes of snow.
Entry.5: Still very cold. Dentists at 9 to have tooth completed. At night the snow came down in earnest and after tea snowball fights were the fashion.
Entry.6: When we awoke it was to see a beautiful white mantle over everything and it was a sight I shall always remember. We made snow men and had snow fights until our hands & feet were numb and wet thro. During afternoon the snow eased off and Sam and I went for a walk to Durrington.
Entry.7: Raining. Snow almost thawed by now.. Orderly Room.
Entry.8: Route march in morning. Telegram from Ernie. To Amesbury at night & posted letters (7). Received gas & trench helmets and goggles
Entry.10:
Final preparations for hurrying off tomorrow. On making enquiries for my cable money £4-7-10 I found it had been forwarded to France.

Thursday 
24
 23rd 

Did not sleep too as floor was hard without palaisse & only 2 blankets. So at the appointed hour of rising 3.45 am nearly everyone was awake. 

Then followed cup of tea & light refreshment and after cleaning up we were on parade at 5.30 in total darkness. Moved off at 5.45 and soon got quite warm. In addition to our valise well packed we carried 2 blankets one waterproof sheet one service cap 1 haversack packed 1 water bottle filled 2 gas masks & 1

Pair tear shell goggles 1 steel helmet 1 mess tin filled 1 tucker bag, filled 1 pouch filled as well as sheepskin vest & greatcoat. Entrained at Amesbury and was lucky enough to be with John Driver Ron Hill Jack Perry the four of us being only ones in our compartment – the majority carrying eight. Without much delay in 1½ hours we arrived at Southampton at about 9 and heaving our packs on wharf we were allowed to walk the wharf. We were there until 7 pm. Then we fell in & marched on board our ferry transport boat the Queen a paddle steamer. We pushed off at about 8.

Things went well for about an hour or so – although it was raining upstairs & crowded downstairs. 

At sea we struck bad weather and then the fun commenced. Soon ninety percent of those on board were sea sick. I must confess that altho’ we were 10 weeks on our trip from Aust – yet I never felt it as I did this trip. I went upstairs for air on one occasion and the confusion was indescribable. There were men everywhere throwing up also downstairs – none were particular.

(We had on board the whole of our Ambulance (less transport) the Light Blues, Purple & Red (A) and English Drafts)

Owing to the rough seas we did not arrive in France until 6 am next morning. One of the first things that met our was a British Red Cross Hosp

a beautiful glass looking building.
Entry.11: At daylight we were put shore at Havre and a cup of tea was made for us. At 10 we moved off again and arrived at a Rest Camp about 2 miles away in due course. Saw plenty of German prisoners huge broken guns and war necessities en route. At the Rest Camp we met some Australians back from the “Somme" and other “Tommies". Put into bell tents (10 in a tent) and somewhat crowded. At night we visited the YMCA in the Camp and chatted to a Scotch lady who was working here for a few months. Also chatted to a Belgian soldier. He was wounded at & was at & Antwerp and after making munitions in England was now employed at same work here. Into bed as best we could and rain in night made things very uncomfortable.
Entry.12: Reveille at 6.30 am. Still raining heavy. Pack up kit & cup of tea etc and at 8.30 we were ready to move off again. March to station and packed into cattle trucks – 35 in each – still wet through. Then followed a dreary time prolonged by delays en route. We passed Rouen at midnight. Tea at but could not sleep as we were too cramped. I sat up all night and generally spent an uncomfortable time.
Entry.13: Our train pushed on rather slowly and only covered 75 miles during 15 hours. However at about midnight we arrived
Entry.14:
at Abbeville and procured a cup of tea. During the day the sun shone and the scenery en route was rather good but the low lying parts were flooded. There were several troop trains in front & several behind us which accounted for our slow progress. Could not sleep again but noticed that we passed thro’ Ettapes, Boulogne & Calais. Then on 
passed
 past Hazesbruck on to Ballieul where we were pleased to disentrain. After cleaning up our train we were put on to “London buses" commandeered for purpose & 
drove
 carried to our billets at Steinwurk (Steenwerck) a village midway between Ballieul & Armentieres.

OUR FIRST GLIMPSE OF WAR

We had not been there long before we witnessed a go between German anti aircraft guns & one of our machines. The aeroplane got away safely. The peculiar black smoke of bursting shells was easily distinguished as German explosive. The guns could be distinctly heard. We obtained billets in a hospital (empty) and given leave for a few hours. We took advantage of this 

to look round Steenwerck.

 
Monday 27th
Entry.15:
Gas mask drill in morning. In afternoon was placed to guard Red Cross Stores and acting as Storeman. It was just here that I noticed the network of underground passages in our

billets.

Saw by an English paper that a raid was made on the Channel by German destroyers on night of 23rd inst. – the night we were transported across to France. After tea I went for a walk around village and succeeded in falling into a dirty trench used as a gutter. To make things more uncomfortable water was hard to obtain.
Entry.16:
When I awoke it was to learn that I was – with 19 others to go up to the lines and run a Divisional Baths at Nieppe – quite close at Armentieres. After breakfast we set out along the muddy road and after a couple of hours arrived at Nieppe and it was interesting to see the damage done by German guns. The Town Hall & Church were especially suffering. A tram line was partially closed & had not been used recently & along the road the place teemed with old trenches & barbed wire entanglements all relicts of German invasion. quite close to us is Estaires another town which suffered. In due course we arrived at our destination and “A" section who accompanied us continued on to the trenches at Chappel D’Armentieres. 

The Baths were an enormous undertaking and a detailed

account of its working will follow later.

We were quartered in a concrete floored building at rear & during the afternoon we put thro’ 500 men, which was entirely satisfactory.
Entry.17:
Pay to day. For the first time our Pay books were marked “Paid in the Field" £1-8-8 (we were paid 40 francs)

Met Norman Siddens of Lhardt He is in 4th Div and had just returned from the Somme this morning.

The Divisional baths were closed all day to square up and prepare for working them in earnest. Reinforcements arrived for us this morning as it was found impossible to run the show properly under 60 men.

Just here it is interesting to note how the civilian population still carry on with their work notwithstanding guns machine guns shells 
star shells can
 make a noise as if only a few hundred yds away. They are only about 3 miles off and there is a battery of artillery in an adjacent field that rattles all our windows frequently.

Cannot emphasise the shocking need for fresh water in these parts. It is almost impossible to obtain and the tea we drink is always flavoured with alum (used for clarifying)
Entry.18:
Baths still closed. Was on sanitary work of Baths yesterday & today. Received a bumper mail today (I received no less than 18) In our billet there are 3 pairs of German top boots probably Ulans left when they evacuated this town. At 6 pm Major Honman lectured us on our several duties for tomorrow and I was a Lance Corp. in charge of sanitation. Some job. 

It might be stated that Armentieres is practically surrounded by Germans and a sudden advance by them would cut us off.

Picking up the French lingo by degrees

ARMENTIERES
Entry.19: Baths going again. Put thro’ about 600 today.
Entry.20:
Received about 17 letters Australian mail, Also the proceeds of my cable, £4-7-10

This afternoon with Jack Driver to Armentieres and saw our Dressing Station & Hospital. Beautiful & up to date town was my impression of Armentieres. the red brick with white facings being particularly pretty. A large Cathedral had been badly damaged. Received parcel from Harold Baldock. Got used to seeing the word Estaminet (tavern)

DIVISIONAL BATHS
Entry.21:
Received tin cigarettes from Miss Sinclair and parcel from McIlraths bearing no name of sender. Also rec’d 4 letters from Australia. Clear night severe bombardment from heavy guns. Some seemed to burst quite near.

Gas attack signalled but only confined to a local area on left flank.
Entry.22:
Outline of the routine for men passing thro’ the Divisional Baths.

The O.C. of the party obtains a chit from the office shewing number of men to be bathed. The men are then lectured as to instructions and they pass in by front entrance. On right they leave their valuables and then on to undressing room. Leaving their under clothes on they pass into the Bath Room. Whilst they are bathing a man takes their clothes into the ironing room where they are brushed, the seams ironed & painted with insect grease

When the men arrive in Bath Room they take off their dirty clothes, hand them in, get a check for them & obtain clean clothes. They then have their bath in the vats provide for purpose. About 1500 are put through each day.

Whilst the above is proceeding another department is boiling clothes – handing them on to 120 women who wash them. They then go thro’ the hydraulic press thence up the shoot to the drying room upstairs.

It takes clothes approx 5 hours to become thoroughly dry. The Sanitary system of France or of these parts at any rate, is absolutely bad. Urine & foecies are thrown haphazardly about and the soil thereby is all foul.
Entry.24: Inspected the upstairs drying room with Sam and from the outside platform caught a glimpse of the River Lys and the Bridge (Pont de Nieppe). It was a beautiful scene added to by the beauty of the moon which to night was shining. Have not commented on the scenery of France as it is now winter and everything has the dull appearance. At night we met a New Zealander in a coffee house who was to marry a French girl next Saturday. He had purchased a house in anticipation.
Entry.25: Raining. Received socks & mittens from Miss Waterhouse. Very bad war news coming thro’ just now. The enemy is overrunning Roumania.
Entry.27:
Sent a registered letter to W Hough Amesbury re watch. Also enclosed 6 francs. Exchanged a P/N (British) at Field Post Office. Had tea in Nieppe. During afternoon a big gun gave us a shock occasionally. It was just behind our billet. But the capper of the day came

when we visited Nieppe and saw on return journey a battle that was progressing south of us, probably Estaires. To hear the roar of numerous heavy guns to see the star shells and other shells bursting was a sight that hypnotised us for a while. It was grand.
Entry.28: Sergt Williams & Geo Pickering have not been too well for some days and today they were both sent to Hospital. Probably influenza. Consequently I filled the position in Orderly Room and found things rather busy today. Had my head down all day on returns, and wages etc. and bed at 10.15.
Entry.29:
Still going hard on C Section Acquittance Roll and returns but outlook better than yesterday. By night things were pretty straight.

 Ommission
 Yesterday was one of the clearest we have had for some time consequently air craft were active and a German nearly flew over our Baths. Quite a number of the ‘scraps’ took place during morning plainly visible to us and a German machine was brought down near Armentieres. The white of ours and black powder of enemy’s was clearly marked.

Tuesday (contd) Snowing rather heavily in morning but not cold.
Entry.30:
Things pretty straight.

Heard that a message had come thro’ in night to say that a strafing was expected. Therefore additional picket were put on but without event.

Sent P/N’s to W Hough Amesbury for watch.
Entry.32:
Warned against leaving our huts without shell helmets and masks. This has been done for past three nights now. Good mail for Australia. Received about 6 letters.

Sergt Williams has recovered and came back today but has a couple of days on light duty. Feet not too good. First sign of chill blains. Put it down to not 
being
 having so much exercise of late.
Entry.33:
At tea time had some fun with bon bons etc. Hogged the contents of a parcel the major gave us. Later 3 parcels for Harold Williams – more hogging.

Clear day again and more aeroplane activity & anti air craft guns.

Laundry Hands. Pay Day
Entry.34: Had rest. Sergt Williams & Geo Pickering carrying on in office.
Entry.35: Letter from home. Restarted work on Sanitary Party.
Entry.36: Recd letter from bro Ernie from Weymouth. snowing in afternoon.
Entry.37: Fine day. more aeroplane activity. Some good stunts.
Entry.38:
Letters to H J Baldock

& bro Ernie. Raining all day.
Entry.40:
Some peculiar sayings drop out sometimes and one today was typical. Word had come through that the Commander in Chief of 2nd Army Corps would be in District today & the men were told to keep an eye & be careful to salute. Consequently one of the boys came into the billet at a great pace & announced that the Commander in Chief would be ‘prowling’ around today. Prowling has it.

Very clear day & great aerial activity. Saw some rare fighting in the air.
Entry.41:
Went into Armentieres in the afternoon with Corps Chas Hamblin & Joe Nankevil & had a good look around notwithstanding that aircraft guns were crackling all around us. After tea we adjourned to YMCA & spent the evening singing Christmas Carols & Hymns & subsequently listened to a natty little sermon by a South Australian.

On return we were surprised to see Col Maguire waiting with a load of ‘Comforts’ & each of us received a pudding & packet of things from the Comforts Fund (Each packet contained packet cigarettes (Peter Pan) small tin tobacco, Tin boiled lollies, writing pad, playing cards & some nuts). I also recd letter from bro & parcel from Mrs Hodge of Crookwell. The Colonel shook our hands all round & wished us merry Xmas.
Entry.42:
1916

Monday 25th Christmas Day

It rained like billeo all night and accompanied with the rain was a particularly severe bombardment by our boys. In fact it was just one continual roar for some time. I was on duty all day but the dinner we had was truly worth remembering.

Some day previous the boys had got a turkey from the village & potatoes & a host of other things which only cost us about 5 Francs each. The menu was excellent and we were lucky enough to get a holly branch making it appear O.K. Turkey, baked spuds, pickles cabbage, bread, Coffee & milk (tinned stuff but good) then to follow Tinned pudding from the Comforts & tinned fruit nuts boiled lollies ginger & dates in galore. How’s That. We have enough over to last tea time.

Burkitt & Egan & I have just completed the erection of new latrines & they are some. Souvenired all the material. Today the river has flooded & is only about 2 ft from flooding us out of our billets. All the surrounding country is one sheet of water and it was no wonder that no progress could be made in this region in previous winters. (River Lys) Very strong wind today & rather cutting too.

This afternoon am doing

Orderly Room work as all the staff have gone to Armentieres to dinner. 

Apres the dinner
 several toasts were drunk in coffee including the King, Our Absent Friends & Loved Ones with which was coupled Our mothers wives & sweethearts & sisters and relations & friends. Also ‘The ladies’ who donated our Comforts. At night terrific bombardment.

Tuesday 26th
Entry.43: Working hard again. Saw ‘Battle of the Somme’. Pond in next paddock caused by overflow from River frozen again. Beautiful grey blue mist.
Entry.44: A beautiful white covering on ground looked exactly like snow but turned out to be hoar frost. It was very nippy and the ice on pools was ¼ to ½ thick. Watercart contents were frozen. Aeroplane activity. Ten of our boys transferred to A.D.S. and last night 10 came to relieve them. Received watch from W. Hough Amesbury repaired.
Entry.46:
Scotch parson to tea

Saturday 30th

Pictures at night Saw ‘Gentlemen of Nerve’ River rising again after heavy rain. Whilst doing the rounds encountered a Belgian who had tied his barge up to our wharf. It appears he was to unload coal.

Sunday 31st New Years Eve

River still rising and is over the wall of our wharf. I spent the night making 

a path to the cookhouse as we expected all our ground to be flooded tomorrow. Had on gum boots & saved some salvage. This afternoon had afternoon tea with Madame in tuck shop in Pont de Nieppe with Sam & the boys. Walk to Nieppe.

A terrific bombardment is just commencing probably to usher in the New Year (11 pm) Forgot to mention that 5 of boys were transferred to A.D.S. today

1917
Entry.47:
New Years Day

More bombardment – and at 2 am this morning a daddy one which lasted some time. Water still rising though not so quickly.
Entry.48: River has gone down a little so danger at present is averted.
Entry.49: Very cool & strong wind today. To Pictures at night Saw Chaplin in “Pangs of Love" & “Mary Queen of Scots" awful Then had fish & eggs at tuck shop. Very tricky the bowls without handles to drink out of. Was up in night – not too well
Entry.50:
Spent morning in bed Did not eat anything

except Army biscuit & cup of coffee which Sam brought. Eating the biscuit I snapped off one of front teeth. Consequently as I got well again about 12 I spent afternoon in Armentieres having the tooth repaired. At night I saw the 3rd Div Follies or Pierrots in the Ecole Theatre Armentieres & a very good show it was. Back with Sergt Williams to Baths.
Entry.52: Letters from Sth Africa & Bro Ern.
Entry.53:
Moved our billet to front of baths as the old one was needed for other work. Spent all morning transferring our goods & chattels.

FIRST VISIT TO FRONT LINE

At 1.45 pm Joe Nankevil & I obtained ‘duty pass’ to A.D.S. & proceeded on our way thereto. Passed Armentieres Railway Stn. where the sentry was very particular. Then down roadway & as we progressed we nearly walked on top of some of our batteries pounding away at Fritz. On one occasion I was passing an opening in a wall when I saw a flight & was nearly swept off my feet with the concussion of one of our big guns. Couldn’t hear for some seconds after. From here onwards we had to be careful & keep close in to the house to prevent aeroplane detection. At last we came to Chapelle Armentieres & one of the boys showed us where shells had

fallen only yesterday. Our A.D.S. was in an old Brick Kiln and very comfortable except for the rats which are more like cats. The Purity League was working here and business was slow. After getting this far we decided to visit R.A.P. and receive instructions as to route. Entering trench behind the A.D.S. we wound round & round it seemed until at last we reached the R.A.P. which was in an old shelled dwelling most of the dugouts were sandbagged but ours was not. It was good to see how nicely the trenches were drained & floored. The boys at R.A.P. were Roy Egan, Chas Hamblin, Mealey & Macey and they soon made us at home. Tea was on and consisted of porridge dry rations tea bread & jam. was cook & the whole feed was grand & enjoyable.

Then Charlie shewed us upstairs from where we could see “No mans land" & surroundings & on a clear day Lille. Soon after dark transports brought ammunition & food up & kicked up a deuce of a noise. Yesterday afternoon some shells fell in the back garden of the R.A.P. but did no damage. On way back (at about 7) we stopped with Sam in his dug out for a while & pushed on & arrived back in

good time. With the exception of a continual bombardment by our boys there was nothing doing.
Entry.54: came up for a bath today & he told us that Fritz dropped about 70 near R.A.P. this morn. No casualties reported to date. Very cold wind this afternoon. Reced numerous papers tonight.
Entry.55: Very cold today. Extra special bombardment tonight.
Entry.56:
Saw a very usual sight this afternoon. Two of our observation balloons were up from midday (sausage type) At about 4 pm I was working in the back of Baths near our Incinerator when a bright flare lit up the sky and looking in the direction was astounded to see the object diving to the earth from a good height leaving behind a wide trail of bluish black smoke. At same time aircraft guns from all directions opened fire and it was then that I realized a German had settled one of our balloons. Our guns gave him a hot time but he evaded them & when over his own lines the enemy aircraft guns also opened fire giving the impression that he was disguised as one of ours. It was a grand sight.

It may be interesting to describe an Estaminet scene (I have often been delighted to visit to see the fun) They are not like our Hotels and the villages simply abound with them. There is a counter in some case where the beer etc is handed over. You walk in get your drink & sit down at a table of which there are usual a dozen in each outfit. Then the piano starts & fun commences & more you drink the better you sing. Style Compre. At 8 o’clock (weet heure) kick out time comes.
Entry.58: Did not get to sleep until midnight as Phelan & Wilson created a disturbance – after being paid - by coming home shiggered & ended up by tossing things about a little.
Entry.59: Mrs Bs birthday. Sent a F.S.C. tonight Also recd a letter from Ernie & answered it. Today has been coldest for some time & I spent all the afternoon working in snow fall accompanied by little rain. Glad of a bath & change. Sam at a Gas School at Casserou (?)
Entry.60:
River again in flood and came up very fast during the night – so fast that I spent the afternoon building a path to the cookhouse.

At night I went to Armentieres with Ron Ponton – staying at Marie Choselet’s near Pont de Nieppe (Bridge) for cup of coffee. The method of partaking of . coffee is worth noting. The beans are put thro’ the machine in ordinary way and after making is poured into the peculiar no handled bowls and a dash of rum added. Instead of sugar you are given a small lolly to hold in your mouth whilst drinking and the coffee goes down well. On arrival at Armentieres we went to M.D.S. thence to tea & Church in YMCA. The Rev Capt Mills preaching.
Entry.61: Large Australian mail I received about 14 letters. The snow & heavy frost of early morn made it exceptionally cold.
Entry.64:
This snowing & frosty and very cold At night the Malgars (Ernie Lawless, Bill Howard, Wagstaffe, J. Gocabi ) & mac Wilson & I went to an Estaminet and had a social evening there. Singing etc. Champagne etc. Met Wood having a bath today. He is looking well. Is now a Lieut (Second) and still attached to the M G Coy. Had a good old chat over

STRETCHER BEARING IN TRENCHES

Board matters mentioning that Miss Lang & Mrs Mallard had written him. Also Ces Thompson Bert Fitz & Bert Mulls deaths. He was going in tomorrow at Houplines 
Gillespie broke his arm Friday
Entry.65: Preparing to go to A.D.S. tonight. Sam returned from Gas School today (Casson). At night 7 of us including Ernie Lawless, Wag Howard Wilf Boyles, Rosenthal left the Baths by Ambulance Car and arrived at ADS about ½ hour later. Slept on stretcher. Rats galore.
Entry.66:
When I awoke it was icy cold and the snow which has been on ground for days is still frozen over. After breakfast I was appointed water picket and which on that job our artillery opened fire just nearby kicking up a deuce of noise. Shells commenced to fly about & Fritz replied later. It was hard to distinguish Fritzs from ours. One chap brought up by our R.A.P. bearers with one leg off.

The Tommies coming out are comical and cut some funny figures. Such remarks as, Have a monkey . Have some butterscotch etc when they havnt a cent is typical. This picket game is no bon as plaster falls off the wall all over you

I made a bit of a fire with furniture & making some water hot fixed up the pump which had frozen.
Entry.67: Water carrying & some heavy work. At 5 pm I went on Gas picket (watching for gas attacks) but my shift did not start until 3 next a m so had some sleep in the meantime. On sentry from 3 to 7 am & very cold. A “stiff un" was brought up for Harry the grave digger just before my shift commenced.
Entry.68:
After breakfast slept until midday Then pack up blanket etc and off up trenches to Reg Aid Post. No sooner had we arrived there than two cases came along & later two more. The trench duckboards are terribly hard to walk on as they have a thick coating of ice of a weeks duration. Therefore we preferred the roadway for taking our patients notwithstanding orders to the contrary.

Things went well until night time. Jack Arkins & I were resting on the roadway near Suicide Corner when up went a 
searchlight
 star shell & after a few seconds bang bang bang & then a whizz ------ We didnt wait for more but Jack was down on his face & I made headlong for the gutter

which happened to be a trench & I went into it. They burst on roadway uncomfortably near & when I arose to push on without delay you could have heard my knees shaking although outwardly we were jolly & laughing over our narrow escape. Fritz shelled that road several times during that night & next day but we werent that close. I have had stomach complaint for a couple of days (probably the chlorinated water) and felt very weak. 
About midnight
 spent a couple of hrs without sleep that night. It was freezing too.
Entry.69:
When we took our next patients along we could see several shell holes along the cobbled road & knew that Fritz had had a pleasant night. Was relieved at noon & came back to A.D.S.

All the pools in the neighborhood are frozen the fools amuse themselves by using their horse shoes heels & nails as pr of skates. Good fun. Rested during afternoon & felt much better at night. Slept well.
Entry.70:
On Gas Picket in morning. At noon Fritz got very nasty & sent a heap of shells over near our R.A.P. We could see it all from A.D.S. Some of the boys changing over got some scares. Included in the shells

were some “tear shells" and caused some “crying". Some damage was done however. Today was an excellently clear day and if it were not for snow on the ground the frost & ice etc. & cold we could have enjoyed it. I was unlucky to be selected for R.A.P. again tomorrow so consequently had to be on gas picket tonight. I was again fortunate however as I struck the first shift and so got a decent sleep. Some of the boys of ‘A’ Section were relieved tonight.
Entry.71: Soon after breakfast Fritz got a nasty fit again and sent over 16 H.Es into the paddock adjoin our A.D.S. apparently with the intention of finding some guns there but apart from giving us a fireworks display and earth bath etc nothing happened. At noon thirty we relieved the boys at R.A.P. and had a quiet afternoon. At night the pumps froze & we had to collect snow to boil for tea. Quite successful. Machine gunner playing tattoo. Very fortunate that night, had a good nights rest.
Entry.72:
Near midday I took a walking case down to A.D.S. & rested afternoon. 

Answers any day (Australia) At night troops were moved up the lines in anticipation of a stunt tomorrow (the

Kaisers birthday)

I was astounded however at about 8.45 when word came for me to report to the Baths tonight. I only had 5 minutes to pack up as motor was waiting but soon collected my goods & was on journey in no time. The roads were simply packed with troops. Only took me as far as M.D.S. so had a very cold time to Baths. It was also against orders to walk about alone. Arrived in due course and found that most of our boys had been transferred elsewhere that 50 P B men (5th Div) were taking over & that Sergt Williams was to report to A.D.S. Hence I was to relieve him. Slept well.
Entry.73:
Not
 Kaisers birthday. Not very much doing. Soon got into running at Baths. Quite a rest. At night Sergt Williams pushed off.
Entry.74: Recd letters from Aust. Bath & shave and walk to Nieppe. Still very cold. One day last week it was only 7 degrees (25 below freezing) Everything is frozen that is liquid & roads very slippery.
Entry.76:
Phil Kirkham received 3 stripes in place of Harold Williams who is leaving for 1st Anzac Head Q shortly in Concert Party. Anzac Coves

He reported for duty today at Baths
Entry.77:
Severe bombardment tonight shaking the factory rather severely at times.

Later. Our men to told to be readiness but were not needed except Capt Vickers who left for M.D.S. & worked all night. It appeared that Fritz came over in white overalls & inflicted about 60 casualties on our boys (40th) 51 of whom passed thro our A.D.S. Supper at
Entry.78: Early this morn Fritz came over at Houplines & got a bad doing by the 35th
Entry.81: Bath in the afternoon then walk to Armentieres to E.F. Canteen thence Orderly Room & examined maps of district. Also obtained £1 note that I had left in my paybook in error. Still frosty & snow & ice shows no inclination to thaw. Coffee & egg in Flo’s --- (French coffee shop) then back.
Entry.82: At night to Armentieres with Aust mail.
Entry.85:
Very cold still

Rec’sd 2 letters from M.B.

OUR FIRST RAID. ASSISTING TYNESIDE SCOTTISH

Wrote to Ern & Miss Greg.
Entry.86: Went to Erquinghem. Baths with Major Honman & Capt Vickers. It is reckoned that we are to take these Baths over very soon now hence the inspection.
Entry.88:
A very eventful day. Usual work during the day About noon we got word to “stand by" in anticipation of a big stunt tonight. This of course spoilt all our Sunday afternoon arrangements but took advantage of it by having a spell for an hour. Then Sam & I went up to Madame Nile’s maison and had some coffee. Return to Baths and a couple of slices of bread gulped down in a hurry – then preparation for a nights stretcher bearing (Orders had come for us to report to our HQ after dusk. so we went accordingly)

It was felt somehow that a big stunt was going to take place as every available man was marched with us to Suicide Corner where the motors were already waiting. While awaiting instructions a couple of bullets (strays) whizzed down the street & reminded us that a war was on. Later we were detailed into stretcher parties and accompanied by one of the heaviest bombardments I have ever heard we 
wandered
 crept

past Suicide Corner and thro the trenches to Wine Av Aid Post – bullets whizzing overhead the while. On our arrival at the Aid Post we found a very convenient dug out filled with bearers & Capt Clark of 11th F. Amb in charge. The guns ceased after & we saw it was only a blind. We had about 1½ hrs to wait for 
next
 real stunt so sat quietly whilst outside the Tynesiders who were going over filed past with their peculiar “waddies" revolvers or whatever they selected.

At last after a tedious the whole heavens seemed to bark with flame and every gun in the district spat out death to the Huns. Fritz replied at first with a few “minnies" and one of the boys in our dug out walked to see the fireworks – only to stop a piece of fragment in his chest. There were two of our boys standing immediately in front of him. Another uneventful ½ hr and then – the next 4 hrs was hell. Imagine after a few cases had been bandaged & patched up – a floor covered with a couple of inches of floor & bloody swabs cotton wool shell dressing all over it. Our hands were never free of blood and the fresh blood smell was nauseating 

During the excitement a wounded Fritz reeled in & while dressing him I got a button as a souvenir. The wounded stuck it well notwithstanding there were some bad cases – abdominal especially. We put thro about 50. When we finished we were trying to stumble about with swabs etc up to our ankles and I had a rotten headache. Bombs fuses gun cotton were lying about everywhere too. At last collecting our stuff we retraced our way back to Suicide Corner and got a welcome cup of coffee. Marched back to Baths & arrived turned into bed at 5.30 in morning.
Entry.89: Kept going all day but felt a bit off. Towards night my left eye went crook and suspected last night doings but as it was improved the next morning it was perhaps an ordinary malady. Ben Skelton came in today I had a chat with him.
Entry.91: Writing at night. much warmer now & water running in river.
Entry.92: Most of our boys received instructions to proceed to Erquinghem Baths to commence bathing there tomorrow so at 7 pm a baggage wagon put out & about 30 men leaving Sergt Clem Taylor & self in the orderly Room
Entry.93:
was occupied in transporting stock etc to the other Baths.

NZ officers came to look over Baths prior to occupation. However at night young Donovan (Capt Vickers batman) cooked us a bonny tea of pork chops eggs & chips. All purchase locally.
Entry.94: Cleaning up etc. All frozen pools & river have quite thawed & enjoyable. Forgot to mention that yesterday saw one of our planes brought down from a great height. Did not see what caused it but immediately afterwards saw two Germans making back as a great pace & concluded they were the cause. The falling plane did not come down as quickly as I imagined it would.
Entry.95: Recd instructions to report to Erquinghem tonight so with full pack I in company with about 8 others set out along river bank. And by gee talk about mud & heavy walking and pack seemed about a ton. On arrival at Erquinghem I found good quarters & convenient surroundings & was well pleased with the place.
Entry.96: Heavy day. Letters from Miss Gregory & Ernie.
Entry.98:
At night I recd instructions to carry despatches to Pont de Nieppe & went via River Bank thro a pea soup fog & mud up to the knees wearing thigh boots & oilskin & it was a heavy trip. However after delivering

the despatches & visiting Madames Wable & Nile I returned & on the journey was stopped by 2 officers who inquired my business (it was about 10.30) Got back safely.
Entry.99: The guns just out in the paddock keep me awake by heavily shaking the place (orderly room) where I sleep on my own. Sam heard from Harold Williams whilst in the office at night a dispatch runner arrived inquiring for an officer and it turned out to be Donaldson from Five Dock. He informed me that Chas Bignall had been wounded in stomach.
Entry.100:
Recd letters from bro Ernie & Miss Warren.

RAID AT HOUPLINES
Entry.102:
Got word of
 In afternoon Sam some of the boys & self went across to Pont de Nieppe to visit our old friends inc Madame Wable & Nile. Also with Sergt Taylor called in to see the Estaminet people & had coffee there. Purchased some eggs returned to Erquinghem & had the eggs for tea. Pont de Niepper looked very gay this afternoon with all the new Zealanders in town.
Entry.103:
Got word of another stunt tonight & accordingly had to report to Billets – with all the other boys at 6.30 pm. We were not clearing in the Tenth Ambulance area but were assisting.

Most of our boys had been dispatched to Houplines the “hop over" area and were held in reserve & told to get to bed at once. Sure enough at 8.30 she started & the sight. After an hour the bombardment eased off & we went to sleep. But at 12.30 she opened again & spit fire all Armentieres seemed to be alive with guns. She did not cease until about 2 am. We slept until 5 when our boys returned with the news that raid had been very successful. Regret to add though that 2 of 11th & one of Tenth Ambulance had been killed & several wounded.
Entry.104: Got back to baths again & saw the raiders with faces blackened & excited and got the news from horses mouth. About 1000 had gone over and they got right to third line capturing many prisoners machines & 2 searchlights besides blowing up a “minnie" store. Talk about “Coons" & minstrel shows they cut a funny figure. Wintry at night.
Entry.107:
A beautiful sunny day – little cloudy but with a feel of spring in the air. Aeroplanes were busy all day. One incident of note Observation balloons were up

and just after dinner a Fritz made a dash across to set fire to one. The occupants seeing him coming got into the parachutes & came down. It was a pretty sight. Fritzs missed with his fire bomb continued on at terrific rate & returned & fired with machine guns without avail. Our anti aircraft made things too hot & he got back to his lines. Then appeared from everywhere our aeroplanes and I counted quite close to us about 12.

During the afternoon an Aust mail came & I fared very well getting about 15. At night walk into the village of Erquinghem 

VISIT TO FLEURBAIX
Entry.108: Major ill. Capt Vickers is now a Major.
Entry.109: Recd a good bunch of more letters. At night to Erquinghem for a walk.
Entry.110: Very busy during the morning and after dinner three of us walked thro Erquinghem Bac St Maur on to Fleurbaix. The place was very much broken up – a Church in part being almost demolished by bombardment. There was plenty of evidence of street fighting there as a large number of houses were barbed-up and loop holes thro the wall told a story without words. We returned via Bois Grenier and had tea in Erquinghem. Band & Church Parade in Baths area.
Entry.111: Was surprised when I woke up to see snow falling & had been for some time.
Entry.112: Finer day but extremely biting wind.
Entry.113: Received a good Aust mail. The wind again biting & exposed parts of body soon became numbed. Fritzs bombarding gun positions. To Erquinghem at night.
Entry.114: Very icy wind & snowed during morning.
Entry.115: Awoke to find beautiful sun shine but very cold. Did not last long but became mushy as the day wore on with more snow. An incident with a Fritz aeroplane created some excitement this morning. An aeroplane could be seen flying towards us – very low and being fired at. We did not realize it was an enemy aeroplane and just above the chimney stack in height. Our anti aircraft shells were bursting very low & a nose cap hit the factory wall just above our heads. There was great excitement for a while. It subsequently transpired that he was brought down near Armentieres. The Germans bombarded a factory in Armentieres today killing 6 civilians & wounding one soldier. treated at our M.D.S.
Entry.117:
Quite a mild day Plenty of excitement. In morning one of our observation balloons was attacked by 3 German aeroplanes and after several attempts they succeeded to setting fire to it & destroying it. Meantime the observers had descended in parachutes. The scene was very pretty. After the incident one of our machines attacked one of German planes but the whole time Germans made a combined attack & our machine had to do some marvelous flying to escape which he did.

During the day the guns concealed all around us (5 inch howitzers) opened out & were firing practically all day. Went over to the gun pit of one & stayed there while she fired two rounds. It is wonderful the way the air is disturbed by the report.
Entry.119: Raid on tonight Commenced about 11.30 pm During the barrage Dick Watts & I went over to see the 5" howitzers in action & came away nearly deafened. They were firing a round a minute. They are new pattern guns & throw a shell 60 lbs in weight & do not require shell cases but they put in its stead what is called a ‘doll’
Entry.122:
aeroplanes 

active. Showers of shrapnel fell around us several times.
Entry.123:
Our last day at Erquinghem Baths. I was successful in obtaining a complete new outfit. The Tommies (57th ) Kings Liverpool Regt arrived during the afternoon to relieve us. The afternoon was occupied in packing up & bath etc. Had tea with Dick Watts in the cabinet opposite & it was some tea. Then to Erquinghem to bid farewell to Madame Vandermason & back to Pont de Nieppe Epinet we arrived at new billets at about 10.30. Saw 
Crook
Entry.124: at Orderly Room & was soon O.K.
Entry.125: Heard the good news of the fall on Bapaume & later the fall of Peronne. The Germans retreating 10 miles
Entry.126:
Received letters from Ernie Capetown & Miss

HUNS SHELL PONT NIEPPE

Warren. It was bitterly cold & raining all day.
Entry.127: The Hun sent a H E shell (5.9) into Pont de Nieppe just about dusk to night killing 4 soldiers & 3 civilians (inc 2 children) Our cars & boys brought them in. Two lived for a couple of hours only. I visited the scene & amp; observed that windows in all the surrounding houses were broken & a large hole was made in footpath.
Entry.128: Was on guard all night. Very cold & snowing slightly. More good news.
Entry.129: Still good news from front (Ancre & Somme. Guard duties continue all day.
Entry.130:
SOME SHRAPNEL

Very good incitement this morning which however ended in one of our boys being a casualty. As is customary every morn our Section does physical culture to keep fit & this morning we were on this routine in the courtyard when a Fritz plane came across & sighted us. Consequently in about ½ hr (we were still at culture) whizzing over came a shell & we were soon on our stomach. Never worried much – thought it was a stray & went on again why again – this time she burst in air not far away but we had taken every precaution & no one was hurt. We then received orders to get inside the billets & the Hun kept us his shrapnel all the morning.

We subsequently learnt that Jim Sullivan had stopped a piece in his arm. Sergt Butcher obtained one of the ‘duds’ half exploded a 5.9 thing & very thick too. We are waiting for the Hun’s next move. At night a party of us went to Nieppe to see the N.Z. Follies of whom we had heard a good deal & they were excellent too. It quite reminded me of Sydney Follies. The orchestra was a star item – one piece they played The Eternal Walz" being particularly good. During the performance we could hear shells bursting up the road. However we got back after having spent an enjoyable night.
Entry.131: Commenced work this morning at M.D.S. P. Nieppe. Busy with wounded at night.
Entry.132: Still fairly cold. I have been off colour recently – slight influenza but improving now. Busy again.
Entry.134: The Hun bombarded the village again this afternoon in close prox to our Hospital & gave us plenty of work. One kiddie had a piece thro his leg. Towards night H Ray bro of Bill Ray came in sick.
Entry.138: Was to have had an hr off but a fall of heavy snow spoilt everything & I played cards instead.
Entry.139: Very cold today. An officer Lt Stratford was brought very badly wounded and in a low condition. He had one thigh fractured & had lost a good deal of blood. We got to work on him & after the eather he was still very low. The Major ordered saline injection & we injected about 2½ pnts in about 1¾ hrs. After that his pulse was better but towards morning he was down again & Major suggested blood transfusion. Ronny Hill volunteered to give him sufficient blood & one pint was taken. The patient did much better & the next morning had rallied considerably. It was a good safe.
Entry.140: We awoke to find it blowing a blizzard and with snow. The flakes were about the biggest I have seen. However as if by magic the wind stopped & the sun came out & it was quite pleasant. At night we went to the NZ Pierrots & saw a good - I got a program.
Entry.142:
Had a pretty rotten case in today. A young chap with one leg blown off & the other shattered breaking the bone in a number of places. Major attended & it took about

2 hrs to fix him up. Unfortunately he had lost too much blood & he died soon after. Later in the day had the painful task of going thro his correspondence prior to sending it on. Went to Bailleul on one of our Ambulances this afternoon with patients & there saw a Fritzs plane that had been brought down by one of ours.
Entry.143:
When we awoke it was to hear anti aircraft guns going their hardest & we could hear nose caps & shrapnel falling all round us. By the way I might mention that the roof of out billet was of ruberoid stuff & wouldn’t stand too much. Someone informed that it was Good Friday but what difference to others we have had.

SHELLING PONT NIEPPE HEAVILY

During the day General Porter D.M.S. inspected the hospital.
Entry.144: but nothing to identify it as such. Fritz sent over 100 shells into Pont de Nieppe this morning & only damaged the wheel of a gun & in addition did not cause an injury to a single man. Towards night five Fritzs fought two of ours & after a good scrap ours were sent to ground (one on fire) A squadron of our planes settled 3 Fritzs balloons.
Entry.145:
Very busy about midday.

During the afternoon we received the very sad news of the death of 3 of our boys and later the bodies put all our doubts to the wind. They were Sgt Gus Dyer, Ernie Porter & Harry Bridson. Both the latter have brothers in the Amb. It appears that were taking up the rations to Advance Dressing Station when a shell landed practically on them & cut them up horibly. I saw the bodies & they were a sight.

Previous ration carts had had narrow escapes & it was wondered that the sending of rations during daylight still continued. Gas drill later.
Entry.146:
Sleet falling & snowing & cold all day.

WORKING PARTY. HOUPLINES

The funeral of our 3 boys took place this afternoon in the local cemetery & was attended by a good number.
Entry.148: Tried to get in to see the Pierrots but crowded.
Entry.149: Completed my work at M.D.S. Our Section relieved by A Section. Received 3 letters from Australia tonight. Still good news. 11000 prisoners & guns Arras.
Entry.150:
Detailed for a working party to Houplines and proceeded with about 20 others at about 8 am. Very quiet day. Had a good look round the ruins. Saw a shrine in a Church quite untouched whilst the Church was knocked to atoms by shell fire.

returned safely Wrote to home etc in Coffee stall in the “evacuated" area Houplines. Was just hopping into bed when word came that I was to proceed to Houplines again with the night working party & get the bricks. We drove down as far as it was safe to go in with Waggons. Then each wagon was to dash along the road on its own – with ten minutes interval. Arriving at the post we loaded very fast & got away again smoothly as Fritz sprays machine guns on the post occasionally. However things passed O.K. & we proceeded to Steenwerck where the building a huge Dressing Station was in progress. We eventually got back to billets at 3.30 am & had breakfast then bed. Houplines by the way is in Belgium.
Entry.151:
Our slumber was rudely awakened at about 8.30 by the whizzing of shrapnel & perhaps nose caps and as the roof was only Ruberoid I thought it best to get up & put my tin helmet on. On investigating I found that a Fritzs aeroplane was about 100 ft above us & soldiers in streets had a machine gun (Lewis) & rifles playing on him but without effect. Aircraft shrapnel was going dangerously low too. He got away.

 Afternoon
 Visited Divisional Baths & had a ‘bon’ bath.

Heard to night that the Coffee stall at Houplines mentioned yesterday was knocked by a Fritz shell about 5 minutes after the boys left. Eddy came back with his head in bandage having been cracked with a brick. Alf Moss went to suffering from T.B. Walk with mac auley at night.
Entry.152: Fatigue morning. Church with Capt Weir at 11.15. Night on guard Raining. A terrific barrage commenced at about 8 and we learnt that Fritz had come over. Consequently our Advanced Posts had plenty to do & about 40 wounded came through our hands.
Entry.154: Working party at Houplines bricks. On returning to Billets we learnt that we were to be permanent working party at night for some time & were to be billeted at Armentieres. After tea we proceeded to 11th Field Ambulance & thence to billets at Armentieres. Commenced work at 10.15 pm & continued until 3.15 am.
Entry.155: Slept until near midday feeling very fatigued. Afternoon to Pont de Nieppe billets
Entry.156: On late relief at Houplines working party. Material hard to get, so we did not finish until daybreak.
Entry.157:
Early relief finished about two am.

Met Wearne of Liverpool Field Hosp who had come across as Reinfs to 11th Fld Amb.
Entry.158: Completed our work at about 2. To date we had collected about 130 tons of bricks in 4 nights. Germans bombarding Pont de Nieppe & Armentieres rather heavily. I had quite an experience trying to dodge some whilst passing along the road. Met Geo Francis (now Sgt) QM. Fritz very savage today.
Entry.159:
Tonight was to be our last on working party. It was – but we won’t forget it in a hurry. When about half the job was finished – the Germans raided the trenches just opposite to where we were working. At once our barrage fire opened & the noise gee it was some. We finished loading the waggons that were down there expecting any moment for a shell to come over but we were fortunate.

A couple of machine bullets whizzing quite close decided the issue for us & we decided to run the gauntlet along the open road to safety notwithstanding that during a scrap it is always shelled & open to machine gun fire. However after a very anxious quarter of hour we negotiated the road & heaved a sigh.
Entry.160:
Up at 7 
& with full kit we
 marched thro nieppe Nieppe on to our

unit who had just taken over a new Hospital on the hut system. There was plenty of work to do in the way of making roads etc.
Entry.161: Plenty of hard work. To Armentieres with transport for fuel etc. Trip to Belgium at night.
Entry.163: Received good Australia mail. At night went to Follies & Germans shelled Pont Nieppe Bridge and the Baths today.
Entry.164: Quiet day. Still going strong at M.D.S.(new) at Pont D’Achilles.
Entry.166: Today is the first day since October that we have felt warm & it is really hot today. Although it is Sunday there is no spell for us & work continues just same.
Entry.167:
Night To Follies at Nieppe. Fritz sending over many shells behind Nieppe & shook the ground very considerably. At our new M.D.S. water is scarce & for first time on active service we are washing in ditch water. It has been quite warm lately. Fritz got nothing today in the air as in our sector he destroyed 4 planes & 2 captive balloons. Our new machines are a treat we

rename them the “Flies". Four of our boys left today for Blighty to join the Australian Flying Corps. Messrs Fred Toby, Joe Bell Harry Wrench & Boyer. All boys having hair clipped.
Entry.168: Anniversary of our leaving Sydney. Still very hot & pleasant after cold spell. Saw Pierrots at night.
Entry.170: Walk at night to Romarin. Typewriting today for Major Honman. Ted Southern transferred to Sanitary Section. Staff Casson to 11th Fld Amb.
Entry.171: Walk to Romarin & back via fields.
Entry.172:
To Div Baths at Steenwerck towards evening & after a tea of eggs & chips we spent the night sauntering round the town until dusk. Soon after arriving back at Pont d’Achilles there commenced one of our liveliest night to date. Fritz commenced a terrific bombardment and contrary to custom the shells seemed to be all falling in the supports & roads behind the trenches. I proceeded to rear of Camp & from there I got a good view of shrapnel shells bursting about 440 yds away. It was O.K. while they were that far away but whizy 

HUN SHELLING EVERYWHERE

and two shrapnels burst almost above my head. On getting the wind of them I was soon down & escaped injury though pieces fell all around & I could the rattle on the tin sheds of the camp. Thinking it time to quit that position I was surprised to find the Camp practically deserted on my return & ascertained that patients personnel horses & cars had been dispatched across the fields it being the CO’s contention that an attempt would be made to strafe the Hospital. 

After I had set out in search of others quite a number of shells both H.E. & shrapnel fell in close prox to the Hospital. After about an hour the bombard had apparently ceased & we returned to bed only to be called out again in half an hours time Fritz having commenced again. It was then bitterly cold. Fires could be noticed in our lines. On this evacuation I took my blankets & eventually put up in a barn the shelling continuing until nearly dawn. Not much damage was done to Hospital fortunately.

One of our boys from Charing Cross has just informed us that Fritz shelled the A.D.S fairly violently. Wilfy Boyes was having a bath in a basin of water & when one landed just outside he ran across 

naked to get his disc. Some wag Heard of Billy Elms death down below.
Entry.173:
Church in YMCA hut. Not much doing after last night and we were pleased with the spell. However bets were flying about as to whether Fritz would have us up again tonight but in spite of what we thought we got into bed early. About midnight he opened out again & ironmongery began to fly around.

Rather that loose another nights sleep adjourned to the barn across the road & slept comfortably until 6 a.m. It appears that he had a second go about 4 am.
Entry.174:
Light duty Rather a cloudy day. In afternoon took a run along to Follies & towards close of performance a terrific bombardment was heard towards Armentieres. Fritz had been putting over gas gas shells shrapnel H.E. etc. at Houplines & other places & soon the alarm got to us. On hurrying back to billets our syren sounded the alarm & men with their helmets at the alert were all instructed to adjourn to the Fields. After half an hour the wind changed and it began to rain – therefore gas was settled. However we were not disappointed

as I witnessed the heaviest bombardment by Fritz since our arrival. The shrapnel simply rained over. Our boys in retaliation sent over a murderous barrage about an hour after which eclipsed Fritzs. Back to Billets & was not disturbed during the night.
Entry.175:
Learnt that one of the 11th Fld Amb were killed & 
one wounded
 at Brewery Raining today.
Entry.177: Theatre party of Follies. Dick Gates drew cartoon of some of the artistes (Lieut Kerry & Don Nelson) & Bunny Burnside made a presentation of flowers etc after the performance.
Entry.178: Concert in the Parade Hut at night. The Follies (some of them) came down to give us a hand & the whole thing was a great success. Number of our boys returned from the Aid Posts including Sam Crook. We are running an ADS at Charing Cross at present and Aid Posts at Dead Horse Corner Prowses Point. Two men were killed in the next dugout at Prowses Point yesterday & some of our boys suffered from shell shock. Weather still excellent.
Entry.179: Still very hot. Rec’d Australian mail today
Entry.180:
Today I had the unwelcome experience of hearing a German naval shell whizz over or really 4 of them. The report seemed to be quite close but I suppose was in reality about 15 miles away the shell travelled fast for we got the whiz almost immediately. Most of them landed in Steenweck a couple of miles further back but not much damage was done. About 9 inch shells they were.

Walked towards Neuve Eglise in afternoon thence to YMCA to church. Place looks good oh now with all the green leaves etc. & it is a pity that the place is being spoiled by this blessed business.
Entry.182: several odd jobs Raising floors of huts etc. At night Alf Henderson & self left for Charing Cross by car – full gear – and arrived there about 8 p.m. Found the place well protected particularly the concrete dressing station. Slept well in spite of incessant barking of 18 pounders which pelted them in practically all night.
Entry.183:
Directly after dinner we left for Dead Horse Corner R.A.P. and after a very pretty walk thro bush eventually arrived there. The woods looking particularly fresh & green reminded 

(Plogstreet Wood)

me of Edward Ellis descriptions of Indian life & warfare. The wood was teeming with sandbag barricades breastworks miniature railways hutments covered with sandbags etc. On arrival at Dead Horse Corner found it fairly well protected – not sufficiently well though. It consisted of a half circular galvanized iron structure covered with 2 layers of sand bags. Water procured from shell holes which are numerous. Grave of unknown British soldier nearby. This wood was captured by Glostershires in 1914. 

On looking round I was surprised to see enemys front line just on the ridge in front of me seemly about 100 yds away but probably three times as far and the Germans were on the slopes on other side of ridge. However we hadn’t been there long with over came some Minnies and I clambered up on our dugout to see them burst – enormous explosions. Some heavy 5.9s also came over so I sought refuge in the dugout. Was kept awake at post by the bombardment we gave him but slept soundly afterwards.
Entry.184:
Raining constantly all morning but our guns worried him all day.

He sent a good deal back during afternoon. We had a late tea, Alf & I did cooking. Immediately afterwards a terrific artillery duel opened. our shanty was rocking about rather nastily. It continued for an hour. Not many casualties. Fritz raided but was cut up & he did not succeed in penetrating our trenches.

Friday 18th 

Was surprised & pleased to get the news from Major Honman that Sam had won the Military Medal during the heavy bombardment of 5/6 May. The major was highly elated. The order awarding the medal read as follows:-

No 1181 
Sgt Crook S. R.
 9th Aust Field Amb was at Charing Cross Dressing Station during the heavy bombardment of night of 5/6th
Entry.185:
He lost no opportunity in seeing to the safety & comfort of patients & personnel under heavy shell fire. H.E. & shrapnel (20 shell holes are within a radius of 50 yds of dressing station) he assisted at & directed the removal of patients to safety. Later on he led a party to repair holes in the road – removal of broken trees etc. Throughout he showed disregard of personal safety in devotion to duty.

At night Fritz sent over another murderous bombardment & some

heavy stuff again fell very close to our outfit. In the raid that followed an hours bombardment he again failed & was cut to pieces as before. We had a trip down at about 2 o’clock and had a devil of a job owing to ammunition coming up the line. However we got back by 4 am.
Entry.186:
This morning we got an idea of the damage Fritz did during the bombardment. Hunters Avenue was practically a wreck & trees were across the supply trench. Wantage Hall another of our R.A.Ps was very lucky on several occasions and was knocked about a bit. Major Honman went out during the barrage to Wantage Hall. Gassed. used by Fritz are chlorine which attacks lungs, Phosgene heart, lachraematory or tear shells which affects eyes. It is said that he is using Prussic Acid but have not had any on this part of front.

We were all very sorry at Major Honmans death by gas he was one of our most popular officers. Lately he has very irritable probably his nerves were shattered at the length of time in action.
Entry.187:
Fritz lobbed a Minnie in front of Prowse Point Aid Post which made a hole about 30 ft in diameter & about 10 ft deep. One part of our run down to A.D.S. is exposed to machine gun fire

for 50 yds but we have safely negotiated it to date. Fritz darent fire his machine gun in daylight as he would be blown to bits in quick time. Young Knuckles West stopped a shell splinter in his hand but it is only slight.

Our working party making a new Aid Post were shelled out this morning. We were relieved for a couple of days – tonight & returned to A.D.S. where the blessed 18 pounders kept one awake all night.
Entry.188:
Fatigue all day at Charing Cross and at night 4 of us inc Alf Henderson were dispatched to Prowse Point in anticipation of a stunt. From Prowse Point we were guided further up the hillside to a new dugout near The Only Way. We hadn’t been there 5 minutes when orders came for 4 bearers to go to Company H.Q. for wounded. On arrival there they were sent to front line but found to their disgust 4 men killed by a Fritz shell. However they brought the bodies back & reported the matter to Major . They should never have been ordered to the front line for dead men and 
it was known when
 the infantry major 
gave the order
 knew when he gave the order that the men were dead and beyond our aid. However as the business was not expected before 10.30 we

put in our time at playing 500 and the doc (Blumgren) spun a few yarns to pass away time. When darkness Fritzs machine gun bullets began to whizz across the piece of hill over which we were to carry and later an infantry officer warned us that our light was visible. On putting a blanket over the door things were quieter. Time went on and at 10 it began to rain heavily. At midnight a rumour came down with the news that the raid was over – a silent one and there were no casualties. We found it very slippery on return journey & arrived back at Charing Cross at 1.15. No sooner had we arrived

which our guns bogged into it like demons & put up a terrific barrage. We could distinctly see some shells in the air the atmosphere being moist. We learnt that the N.Z’s had raided under the barrage. Into bed at 3 am.
Entry.189:
Still raining when I arose at 9 am. Left Charing Cross at about 11 am with Ambulance & patients & arrived at Pont D’Achilles Dressing Station about midday. From there we walked (Alf Henderson & I) to Steenwerck Baths and had good hot bath later Passed some 4th Aust Div transports on road coming in. After bath we pushed on into the town (Steenwerck) and

purchasing some sausages found a classy eating house & had them fried with eggs & chips and the whole went well. At first the people didn’t want to cook it as today was a meatless day throughout France. Stroll around for a bit thence return per boat to Pont D’Achilles in time for tea. Was surprised at the number of new marquees (duly disguised) & stretchers about the place. There was a pile of stretchers about 12 ft high & 20 ft long. We were lucky enough to get an ambulance on way back Charing Cross and safely negotiated the road to this part of front and it has been evident that a push was in preparation.

Recently our guns have been peppering Fritz & messines & it is almost impossible to sleep in the lines. A.M.C. work has been hurried on new R.A.Ps (not very solid) new A.D.S. & the colossal M D S at Pont D’Achilles at which there are 6 ambulances (9.10.11.4.12.13) all point to activities soon. Our aeroplanes are particularly busy and live over Hunland some even descending almost on the trenches. We have to sew our brassards on & a green ribbon to denote 9th Brigade and all these things 

can be summed up that the push is only a couple of days off. Today I am spending in making final preparations besides having to sew our Brassard on we were each (the bearers) given a piece of green ribbon to sew round the brassard and our left arm looked something like this 

We are to carry on extreme right flank of movement & to act as pivot thereby getting all cross fire etc. Australians are to attack with N.Z. on 4 mile front.

Whizzies to keep us company killing an unfortunate a little near the front than we were. From our Aid Post we could see Messines. German artillery firing & our shells bursting & the sight was unique & impressing.

However Fritz was fairly quiet during night and we made up for our previous nights unrest by sleeping 13 hrs without a break.
Entry.190:
Fairly quiet. Alf & I cooking. At night a bon Australian mail came in & it was good oh! I despatched a couple away. About dark a violent concussion rent the air and the wind rush past us at a enormous speed. Fritz had got into one of our ammunition dumps. He sent a large number of shells over our heads bound probably for Charing Cross way

which Fritz was shelling. On arrival at Charing Cross we got our belongings together & set out through the Subsidiary lines for Wantage Hall & arrived safely to find there an excellent dugout & plenty of room. We found some difficulty in getting thro the trench in parts owing to trees being blown across it during the stunt last Friday and outside of our dugout was quite a dozen specimens of any shells & pieces. A hole a yard away made apparently by 5.9 had cut the dugout sand bags about a good deal and a hole was thro the door apparently the splinter that Knuckles West had stopped.
Entry.191: Down to Dressing Station for rations & water. Afternoon - with Alf toured the Aid Posts thro sunken trench - Rifle House then Dead Horse Cr & returned via Hunter Ave. We sent over some gas tonight & liquid fire. No results obtained yet A heavy barrage was heard a few sectors up north of us.
Entry.192:
Very nice day. Saw 
Mills Bombs
 outside out dugout today. They are scattered everywhere here. Its shape is: 

About 4 inches high & 2 ½ ins diameter with corrugations. Steel about 6 inch explosive amenol.

Some of other contraptions used by us are, Plum puddings (Trench mortars) also “Flying Pigs" (Trench mortar) Rifle grenades & others.

Plum pudding shaped thus. About 1 ft diameter weigh about 60 lbs.

‘Pig’ about 3 ft high with 4 fins on base
Entry.193:
Fritz made it exceptionally warm all the morning and on two occasions I had narrow squeaks. First one – I had just finished shaving – at door of dugout – when whizz-bang and had I not unconsciously ducked, my head would have stopped a number of flying pieces. As it was I got a shower of leaves & sprigs from the tree I was under. A few minutes later I was standing in the trench cooking some rice when bang – and I thought my last hour had come. When I ventured to obtain the culprit that had shocked me I found piece of a nose cap from one of Fritz anti aircraft shells

He had been belting at one of ours just overhead for about a hour.

About midday orders came through for us to process to Dead Horse Cr without a spell as our unit was taking over two new R.A.Ps on the Ridge – Cooks way & The Only Way. To man these shows the whole of C Section had been brought up. We also get the good oil that the stunt was not far off and find preparations were being made.
Entry.194:
Very hot today. Fritz again made it warm & shelled & smashed the railway near Wantage Hall. Our bearers at the Only Way were

OUR RAIDING PARTIES

also shelled out.
Entry.195: At about 1.30 am we sent a raiding party of about 200 over in Prowse Point Sector but success was limited and only secured 1 prisoner & lost about 80 wounded & 10 killed. Our bearers & effectives had to go at top At Dead Horse we were more fortunate and except for the barrage were not disturbed. I received instructions at noon to report to Charing Cross for another stunt to night.
Entry.196:
At 1.45 one of the heaviest barrages I have witnessed was put up by us and the concussion was tremendous. Soon after the wounded began

to roll in and we didn’t have a spare moment until breakfast time. This raid was more successful as majority of wounds were considerably slight. One case that of protruding intestine was interesting as after the patient had slept for 2 hours he felt better and spoke quite sensibly. We sent him on apparently doing well. Slept as well as guns would allow and without any meal proceeded with Sam & others to view our position in the stunt. One of the dugouts had already been dented by a shell and whilst we were inspecting The Only Way Fritz sent over a
Entry.197:
Working party all day on Messines Road building trench near our new A.D.S.

At night we were relieved at Charing Cross & had a good sleep at Pont D’achilles

Thursday 31st 

Morning an excellent bath at Steenwerck. Afternoon working party on Messines Road again until 9 pm. Saw one of our observation

PREPARING FOR MESSINES
Entry.198:
contd

balloons set on fire by a Fritz aeroplane, a good piece of work. Soon after we left Charing Cross Fritz shelled the woods & caught 12 men altogether. Hugh fire could be seen inn our lines with red flash that lit up the whole sky & we learnt that the N.Z were kidding Fritz, he had got onto a dump.
Entry.199:
Writing & preparing for the big stunt. Sam & I & party of 16 to report to R.A.P. Cook’s way tomorrow night. For the past 6 or 8 weeks now huge supplies of ammunition stores foods & large guns have been hurried

Battle of Messines
Entry.200:
Had a decent night out and at 9 am paraded 16 all told including Sam. After a few words of advice from Major we were put in two motor ambulances & hurried away to Charing Cross A.D.S. where we arrived without further incident. On the road we saw some gruesome reminders of a dump that had blown up yesterday at Hyde Park Cr. Party split into two – the idea being for the 16 to work the R.A.Ps during the prelim bombardment. Sam I & 7 others then set out for Cook’s Way Aid Post and had some shrapnel to dodge on the way.

Cooks Way Aid Post is in a very exposed position being right on top of ridge opposite Messines. During the afternoon got things in order & dodged a few shells Fritz put over. However we soon became comfortable. After tea orders came for 4 of us to report to The Only Way and I took 3 others along (it was about 150 yds nearer front line) arriving at 8.30. We no sooner got comfortable when in came patients and we sent for 4 more bearers to assist. We were going practically all night in spite of shelling & had some narrow escapes. The trenches in some parts were extremely for carrying thro.
Entry.201:
Slept until midday notwithstanding that our position was constantly being searched for a machine gun positions. At noon we were relieved by balance of party and we adjourned to Charing Cross. There we had a good meal consisting of rabbit pie & oranges (gift of Y.M.C.A. During tea Fritz began the woods particularly our portion and from that time (about 5) we were continually being heavily shelled. It was easily the worst night I have had.

Alf & I were on duty dispensing hot drinks. At 10.30 gas shells commenced to arrive and for 7 hours they simply over in dozens at a time. The air was soon foul and we reverted to our respirators. He never stopped for an instant. Four dumps were exploded and we were perilously close to two of them. They were a great sight. Both Alf & I got a couple of mouth fulls and felt very queer. Our eyed were also affected. However we felt better later.

 Heavy coughing in a dugout close by we went in and found an infantryman without a mask gasping for breath & took him to Dressing station.

Four of our dugouts were blown in but nobody injured. Dead Horse Cr was also blown in and a bearer killed. (10th Fld Amb). After a short sleep we awoke with an aching head & feeling not too good. Towards morning he finished gas shells & turned H.Es on continuing a heavy bombard all day.
Entry.202:
Improved during day. 40 of our boys carried out a brilliant raid on Fritz in broad daylight securing 6 prisoners. It was almost incredible. At 5.30 our party pushed on 

the Only Way Aid Post and as not much was doing we slept as we have never done before. Turning in at 8 pm we awoke at 8.30 next morning feeling OK.
Entry.203:
Messines looks very battered and scarcely a thing above ground. At 6.30 pm “A" Section bearers relieved us & we proceeded Charing Cross. At 9 pm “B" Section bearers arrived from Billets with instructions for us to go to billets for 24 hrs rest as “hop over" was to take place tomorrow night or by following morning. Almost immediately we opened a barrage on Fritz with almost every gun and the effect was astounding.

However as Fritz commenced to put some stuff back we pushed off to stalk the 4 or 5 mls to our billets at Pont D’Achilles to make the best of a last few hours before the “hop over". The journey back tonight was a corker & we could hardly realize that Fritz done so much damage. Along the road which he had riddled with enormous shell holes (probably 30ft diameter) houses were burning for mile & shells & the remains of dumps were littered everywhere. It was a sample of the Hun at his best.

DAY OF ATTACK

Back to billets at last (the place looked like heaven to us) and after a drink we bedded it and were soon in dreamland.
Entry.204:
Spent the day resting, shaving washing etc. At 7 pm all the bearers were paraded issued with bag of shell dressings etc. and moved off with the wishing of good luck by Colonel. For the early part of the night we were allotted Torque Birth as our waiting place and then came the awful night. At 10 pm the Hun commenced to put gas over and it was Sunday over again. 

He simply rained shells over – in Plogstreet Wood all the roads and in vicinity of all the artillery. By this means all the troops had to pass thro the gas moving up and a good number were gassed. The Artillery were also hampered and could hardly see their sights for tear gas and had to work half hour shifts. However not a man thought of throwing in the sponge. He continued throwing over the gas right up to the attack. After all the men were in position all was quiet except for the whine of gas shells. We didn’t sleep a wink. At 3.10 to the minute our dugout heaved up about 6 inches wriggled a bit and recovered herself. Almost immediately she did 

the same again and we then realized that our mines had gone up and the attack had started. At the same time the artillery opened and the whole country was a mass of lightening and shaking about like an earthquake. As far as one could see the horizon was a mass of flames. This continued for a long time and I think I must have dozed (being on first relief party) and from when I opened my eyes it was to see wounded men walking in and parties of Germans with no more that two of our boys in charge of each party. Then we knew that things had gone well for us, and we were right for the boys gained their objective with exceptionally light casualties and it seems at present that the objective was gained all along the line (the length of which we are present in doubt). At 6 we got the word to start our part of business and moved up accordingly.

Thursday 7th

It was rather a nerve wracking experience moving up for shells were being rained all round us and the rattle of our machine guns helped to make it noisy. However when we arrived at the Only Way and saw the messines ridge and the town we realised how marvelously well our boys had done.

New Zealanders were on 3rd Divn left flank and English regiments (75th Divn) on our right with our
Entry.205:
Divn in reserve). Then we grafted and it was heavy work (we had no sleep or a particle of work since we left Pont D’Achilles and by jabbers it was risky and all of us I suppose almost had trips to somewhere several times. As it was we lost S/Sgt Jack Hoskins – minus a leg, young Wardell (a Reinf) both who died later. Bill Curry with a piece in his chest and Alf Webber badly gassed. A Fritz was shot down quite early in morning and it was worth recording here that work of Flying Corps was almost perfect as now not a Fritz plane can be seen and twenty of our are easily seen.

At midday we were still going our hardest still without food when without slightest provocation we felt the wind rush past and next second up went a mountain of earth which descended wounded three quite close to us. Putting our position down in a fairly safe position we stared at each other. Jack Driver Alf Henderson, Harold Lees & self and almost immediately another came over. We then realized that some huge naval

shells were coming across and decided to hop away as quickly as possible. We had a spell just about 2 pm but at two hours later we were astir again and pushing on to Avenue Aid Post. During the afternoon we learnt that N.Zs had to retire 1000 yds but picked it up again soon after. We worked at this R.A.P. until 4 am following morning & returned to Toquet Berth again for a few hours spell.
Entry.206:
Slept a few hours first for two days & had some food & felt better. However at 2.30 we had pushed off again for the same Aid Post. The attack was continuing during the afternoon but have heard nothing yet except the barrage Fritz is also putting a heap of stuff back and I have just tried to tourniquet a chaps arm which had been blown off about 20 or 30 yds away.

Back to Torquet Berth at about 6 pm & slept few hours.
Entry.207:
Off again at 2.30 to Anscroft Avenue again
 

At about 4 pm a tremendous barrage opened and was repeated again about 8 pm each lasting about an hour. They were easily the heaviest to date and the ground simply rocked with concussion. We learnt afterwards that

Prussian Guards had counter attacked but were cut up. The Hun put over liquid gas shells and every other shell he knew but without shifting our boys. Here the excellent work of the Y.M.C.A might again be mentioned for but for them we would not have had a bite of food during the day of attack & following days. Back to Torquet Berth at 6 pm & sleep.

Saturday 9th 

After rising we did not all go out as usual but two parties went out into Old nomans land and I have to take 4 men out tomorrow at 6 am. Received the sad news that Jack Hoskins had died of wounds. The other ambulances also fared very badly. The 11th Fld Amb lost about 21 wounded or killed & 11th Fld Amb about 8 out of action.

Saw the account of fighting in paper today & it looks good. About 600 tons of explosive was used & 20 mines exploded. The work of our Flying Corps was admirable and during the week of advance over 40 enemy planes were settled by our boys. Gas again tonight.
Entry.208:
Things were very warm all day shrapnel & HE.

simply rained over. One landed just near German collecting cage wounding a man. A squad was sent was sent out to get him and one of boys (10th Fld Amb) was cracked in leg. At 2.30 pm the good news came that some of us were to go to Pont D’Achilles for a spell & at 4 pm we set to tramp the 5 miles. Did not sleep well. Abcess on jaw.
Entry.209: Back at 2.0 pm to Charing Cross & I was feeling very crook & generally run down & neuralgia. Didn’t sleep very much. Fritz lobbed some H.Es near billets all night. Officially announced that our losses during the Messines Battle were 10,000 just 1/3 of the enemy’s.
Entry.210:
Quite early we received the news that we were to be relieved for awhile & at 10.30 am set off for Pont Dachilles being followed all the way by shells. On arrival at Pont Dachilles it was to find Fritz sending over some more of his huge naval shells & one got two or three motor lorries & blew them to bits beside making a hole in the road big enough for a house to go in. Still feeling off color. Had abscess lanced by staff Sgt Godfrey. At 3.0 pm we set out again on the march to Neuve Eglise

where we found the surroundings excellent. Spelled today.
Entry.211:
Still at Neuve Eglise resting. In afternoon I walked into the village of Neuve Eglise and could see our guns on the flat country still belting in.
